coredata.dc:title: An improved interatomic potential function for thermoelectric Mg2Si: A combination study of ab-initio and molecular dynamics method
coredata.dc:creator: Yu, Rui
Li, Guo-dong
Guo, Xiang
Deng, Kang-qing
Pang, Ai-min
Zhai, Peng-Cheng
coredata.dc:description:
Abstract
The appropriate interatomic potential function is of vital importance for the prediction of a material’s various properties in theoretical modeling and simulations such as molecular dynamics. Here we develop an improved interatomic potential for use in thermoelectric (TE) Mg2Si, which is fit to density functional theory and is further verified by the molecular dynamics simulation. We find that this interatomic potential can well predict the structural, elastic, and thermodynamics properties of Mg2Si such as elastic constants, thermal expansion, heat capacity, and thermal conductivity, while these predicted results show good agreement with the experimental reports. This work is beneficial for the development of powerful theoretical modeling and simulations to accurately predict various properties of Mg2Si, which can be also applied in other TE or non-TE energy materials.
coredata.dcterms:subject: Interatomic potentials
Molecular dynamics simulation
Thermodynamic properties
Mg2Si

head.ce:title: An improved interatomic potential function for thermoelectric Mg2Si: A combination study of ab-initio and molecular dynamics method

ce:list-item.ce:para: An improved interatomic potential has been developed for use in Mg2Si.
The MD method for thermodynamic properties investigation was developed.
The structural and thermodynamic properties of Mg2Si is predicted successfully.
Mg vacancy reduced the thermal conductivity of single-crystal Mg2Si significantly.

ce:abstract-sec.ce:simple-para: The appropriate interatomic potential function is of vital importance for the prediction of a material’s various properties in theoretical modeling and simulations such as molecular dynamics. Here we develop an improved interatomic potential for use in thermoelectric (TE) Mg2Si, which is fit to density functional theory and is further verified by the molecular dynamics simulation. We find that this interatomic potential can well predict the structural, elastic, and thermodynamics properties of Mg2Si such as elastic constants, thermal expansion, heat capacity, and thermal conductivity, while these predicted results show good agreement with the experimental reports. This work is beneficial for the development of powerful theoretical modeling and simulations to accurately predict various properties of Mg2Si, which can be also applied in other TE or non-TE energy materials.

ce:section.ce:para:
Solid-state thermoelectric (TE) technology, which can directly achieve the conversion of thermal energy into electrical energy with high reliability and environmental friendliness, has great application prospects and economic benefits in the fields of refrigeration, power generation, infrared detection, and waste heat recovery [1,2]. The efficiency of TE materials is characterized by the dimensionless figure of merit
zT =
α
2
T / ρ κ
, where
α
is the Seebeck coefficient,
ρ
is the electric resistivity, T is the absolute temperature, and
κ
is the total thermal conductivity which includes both electric and lattice contributions
κ
e
and
κ
l
. A good thermoelectric material requires the perfective combination of the high Seebeck coefficient, decreased electrical resistivity and low thermal conductivity.

Mg2Si as well as its related compounds have been recognized as the potential high-performance TE material at the intermediate conversion temperature range of 500–850 K [3,4]. In addition to their high thermoelectric performance, their abundant raw materials, low cost, non-toxicity, lightweight (density: 1.99 g/cm3), elevated compression strength (1640 MPa) and Yong’s modulus (120 GPa) make them even more attractive in the commercial applications [5–7]. In recent years, significant experimental characterization efforts [8–12] and theoretical treatments [13–26] have been made on Mg2Si. Liu et al. [27] reported that the zT value had reached 1.3 for Sb doped Mg2Si0.3Sn0.7 by experimental study. Theoretical treatment, which is mainly adopted by using first principles calculation, was focused on the study of electronic structure [13–15], lattice dynamics [16,17], lattice stability [15,18,19], thermoelectric [20–22]and elastic properties [13–15,23–26] of Mg2Si and Mg2 X (X = Si,Ge, Sn and Pb) based alloys.

Nowadays, large-scale molecular dynamics (MD) simulations, which is a popular alternative to the experiment, has been also regarded as a well-established and useful tool in material research to evaluate many properties [28–30]. Especially, the MD can provide the fruitful insights into the dynamics of atomic level phenomena that cannot be observed directly from the experiment. However, there are few theoretical investigations on elastic and thermodynamic properties of Mg2Si by molecular dynamics (MD) method. The difficulty has been due to the establishment of appropriate interatomic potentials. In MD simulation, suitable interatomic potentials are essential for predictions of the elastic and thermodynamic properties of Mg2Si. Nevertheless, no suitable potential function has been reported so far, which limit the development of theoretical modeling and simulations in the Mg2Si TE semiconductor.

In this work, we develop multi-body interatomic potentials including bond and angle interactions for Mg2Si by the first principles calculation. By analyzing the structural stability, the detailed atomic interaction forms including bond and angle items are constructed, respectively. In order to determine the values of parameters in the potential function, the related ground-state equations are established. Based on the cohesive energy and elastic properties from first principles calculation and experiments, the potential parameters are determined through the least-square fitting method. Then, the MD simulation is performed to validate the interatomic potentials by calculating the radial distribution function (RDF), structural and elastic properties of Mg2Si. Finally, the several important thermodynamic properties, including linear thermal expansion coefficient, specific heat capacity and lattice thermal conductivity are also predicted by MD simulation. The potential using in this paper is not complicated in the form. However, this improved Morse potential model has been successfully developed by our group to figure out the atomic interactions and to predict thermodynamic properties in CoSb3 and Zn4Sb3 thermoelectric materials, respectively [31,32]. Especially, this potential model can be used to accurately describe the thermodynamic properties under various point defects [33–36] and large structural deformations [37,38]. We believe this improved potential function is not only suitable for a perfect system, but also for a more complicated system such as the one with structural point defect or large structural deformation. Here, using this improved Morse potential model, we probed the atomic interactions in Mg2Si system and developed the molecular dynamics method for investigation of the structural and thermodynamic properties. These predicted results show good agreement with the experimental reports. Our developed force field method for Mg2Si is a valuable tool for predicting material properties, which is beneficial for the development of powerful theoretical modeling and simulations to accurately predict various properties of Mg2Si.

Mg2Si is a cubic TE semiconductor crystallizing in the antifluorite structure with one molecular unit per primitive cell and four formulas per fcc conventional cell [23]. The structure symmetry of Mg2Si is
O
h
3
with the space group of
Fm
3
‾
m
. The silicon atom locates at the 4a (0 0 0) Wyckoff site and Magnesium atom locates at the 8c (0.75 0.25 0.25) Wyckoff site, respectively [14]. The crystal structure of Mg2Si is shown in Fig. 1 . The axis angle is 90°, 90°, 90° and the experimental lattice constants a = 6.338 Å [39].

The adopted interatomic potentials comprise of bond and angle atomic interaction functions. The long range electrostatic interaction was not considered in our MD simulation, because this interatomic potential function focuses on studying the structural and thermodynamic properties of Mg2Si, rather than the electric properties. The angle interaction is described by the bond-angle function which is the angle bending deviation from an ideal geometry [42]. It is defined as

ce:section.ce:section-title: Determination of parameters of the interatomic potentials
ce:section.ce:para: For bond interaction potential energy function, three kinds of bond interaction are constructed. They are Mg-Mg, Mg-Si, and Si-Si interactions, respectively. For each bond interaction, there are three parameters to be determined. Thus, there are nine parameters to be solved in the bond interaction potential energy function.

For the angle interaction potential energy function, there are two kinds of angle interactions are considered. One is the angle form by two Mg atoms and one Si atom (Mg-Si-Mg angle interaction), the other is the angle form by two Si atoms and one Mg atom (Si-Mg-Si angle interaction). There are two parameters to be determined for the angle interatomic potential, since θ 0 can be obtained from the equilibrium atomic coordinates.

The equilibrium bond distances and angles are listed in Table 1 . Totally, there are eleven parameters to be determined for the interatomic potentials. These parameters would be determined according to the ground-state equations as discussed below.

When a unit cell reaches the equilibrium state, the internal stress is zero in all directions and the potential energy equals the cohesive energy [38,43,44]. It leads to Eqs. (4) and (5)

In the calculation, the Voigt notation is employed to convert the fourth order tensor into a second order tensor. The tensor and matrix notations can be converted to each other: 11 → 1, 22 → 2, 33 → 3, (23 or 32) → 4, (31 or 13) → 5, and (12 or 21) → 6. V 0 designates the equilibrium volume.

To obtain the more accurate interatomic potentials, lots of input data are required. For binary compound Mg2Si, according to the structure shown in Fig. 1 and the equations above, the atomic structural character, cohesive energy and elastic constants must be used as the input data. Therefore, it is necessary to calculate ground-state properties of Mg2Si.

The ground-state properties of Mg2Si were calculated by using Vienna Ab initio Simulation Package (VASP) [47,48] with the projector augmented wave (PAW) method. The exchange-correlation potential was treated by the Perdew-Burke-Ernzerhof (PBE) form of the generalized gradient approximation (GGA). The cutoff energy of the plane-wave was set at 350 eV and the accurate energy convergence is 10−3 eV, which gives good convergence on the stress, energy and geometry.

The optimized energy is shown in Fig. 2 . When the volume is V = V 0 = 257.597 Å3 and the corresponding minimal energy is E 0 = −36.137 eV. The cohesive energy per unit cell of Mg2Si can be calculated by subtracting total energies of corresponding isolate atoms from that minimal energy (E 0). The calculated cohesive energy per unit cell is Ec = −32.57 eV. Generally, the cohesive energy refers to the total energy released when isolated atoms combined into solid, which is important for the stability of crystal structure [15,49].

There are three independent elastic constants for Mg2Si. They are C 11, C12 and C 44, respectively. The elastic constants determine the stiffness of a crystal against an externally applied strain. In Eq. (8), C 11, C12 and C 44 are grouped into three sets of equations against strains of εij = εkl = ε 11 = 1%, εij = ε 11 = εkl = ε 22 = 1%, and εij = εkl = ε 23 = 1% respectively. Here, the values of three independent elastic constants are from the experimental data [39]. Therefore, the following three equivalent strain equations related to elastic constants are obtained,

Altogether, a total of seven related equations (Eqs. (10)-(16)) are established, and there are eleven parameters to be determined. The least squares method, which is an effective approach in data fitting, is adopted to optimize nonlinear equations and obtain an optimal solution by using MATLAB program. The optimization solution of the nonlinear equations means to find optimal parameters which keep sum of the squares of the errors resulting from every single equation mathematically, there are infinite groups of eleven parameters which satisfy the eight nonlinear equations. Here, the eleven parameters have their physical meaning and the value range. Therefore, the optimizing region of parameters should be limited. For instance, since the first near neighbor interaction are considered in the calculation, equilibrium distances of Mg-Mg, Mg-Si and Si-Si bonds are 3.1814 Å, 2.7552 Å and 4.4992 Å, respectively. In bond interaction functions, the values of equilibrium bond distances (r 0) for Mg-Mg, Mg-Si and Si-Si should approach the values of 3.1814 Å, 2.7552 Å and 4.4992 Å, respectively. For most materials, the stiffness parameter (α) and the depth of the potential well (D) must be positive and not more than 5.0 [32,38]. Considering the physical significance and optimizing ranges of the parameters, the optimal parameters are obtained, as listed in Table 3 .

By using the parameterized interatomic potentials above, molecular dynamics simulations can be put into practice to verify the feasibility of the interatomic potentials. In this section, molecular dynamics simulations are performed to obtain the structural and elastic properties of single-crystal Mg2Si, and the results are to be compared with those from first principles calculation and experiments. The periodic boundary condition is applied along all directions. The classical list algorithm of neighbor atom is implemented to calculate the forces exerted on the atoms. The time step is set to 1 fs. All the models are kept at constant temperature, which is based on direct velocity scaling method [50] by Maxwell distribution. The Velocity verlet algorithm [51] is adopted to integrate into Newton’s equation of motion. The Nose/Hoover temperature thermostat and Berendsen [52] pressure approach are applied to control the temperature and pressure of the system, respectively. All simulations are performed by using the Large-scale Atomic/Molecular Massively Parallel Simulator (LAMMPS) developed by Sandia National Laboratory [53].

To confirm the structural stability of single-crystal Mg2Si after relaxation at room temperature, the radial distribution function (RDF) of single-crystal Mg2Si was analyzed and depicted in Fig. 3 . It is known that RDF provides information about the probability of finding an atom in a spherical shell at a distance r from an arbitrary atom, and successive peaks in the figure represent positions of the atomic neighbors. Lots of structural information such as bond length, atomic bond angle distributions, crystalline symmetry, and coordination numbers can be obtained from the radial distribution function.

Fig. 3 shows the radial distribution function at the temperature of 300 K. The peak in the figure shows the position of the first nearest neighbor. The figure illustrates that the bond lengths are at 3.1875 Å for Mg-Mg, 4.5105 Å for Si-Si, 2.7565 Å for Mg-Si, respectively. The bond lengths obtained through crystal structure optimization by first principles calculation are 3.1814 Å for Mg-Mg, 2.7552 Å for Mg-Si, 4.4992 Å for Si-Si, respectively. The MD results agree well with that from first principles calculation and indicate that the single-crystal Mg2Si maintains stable structure after relaxation at room temperature.

In order to confirm the reliability of interatomic potentials, the structural and elastic properties of single-crystal Mg2Si are calculated by MD simulation. The simulation system size along the three perpendicular directions of [1 0 0], [0 1 0] and [0 0 1] is 31.69 Å, 158.45 Å, 31.69 Å respectively. During the relaxation process, the volume is allowed to shrink or expand at zero pressure. The time step is chosen as 1 fs. After 50,000 steps of relaxation with NPT ensemble at the temperature of almost 0 K, the radial distribution functions in various models of single-crystal Mg2Si are plotted in Fig. 6. By applying 1% uniaxial small strain deformation along different directions, elastic constants C 11, C 12 and C 44 can be obtained from the stress-strain responses. The structural and elastic properties of single-crystal Mg2Si are listed in Table 4 . Our calculated results show good agreement with first principles calculation and experimental results, which verifies the feasibility of the interatomic potentials.

The linear thermal expansion coefficient is of both theoretical and practical importance. Together with the specific heat capacity, they are essential in predicting the thermodynamic equation of state and in evaluating thermal stresses induced by temperature fluctuations of statically indeterminate structures [54,55].

Thermal expansion coefficient is obtained from the temperature derivative of the lattice constant a at zero pressure,
(18)
α
l
( T ) =
1
a ( T )
da ( T )
dT
Fig. 4 presents the lattice parameter of the single-crystal Mg2Si as a function of temperature. It can be found that the lattice parameter increases linearly with the temperature. The fitted linear expansion coefficient of single-crystal Mg2Si in the temperature range of 300–800 K is 1.21 × 10−5 K−1. To our knowledge, no experimental measurement on thermal expansion coefficient of Mg2Si is available to date. The volume thermal expansion coefficient
α
V
of Mg2Si was estimated to be 3.27 × 10−5 K at 300 K [56]. And the equivalent linear expansion coefficient
α
l
is 1.1 × 10−5 K−1. The calculated linear thermal expansion coefficient from the molecular dynamics simulation is in good agreement with the experimental value.

Heat capacity is the physical quantity that characterizes the amounts of heat against the change of body temperature. The heat capacity of single-crystal Mg2Si is computed by the following formula:
(19)
C
p
=
∂ E
∂ T
where E is the total energy per mole of the material, T is the body temperature, and Cp is the mole heat capacity. In this section, all simulation setups are the same as those in the previous section.

E-T curve of single-crystal Mg2Si from 300 K to 800 K is plotted in Fig. 5 . The total energy per mole increases nearly linearly with the growing temperature. A relationship between E and T is obtained by fitting the E-T curve to a linear function. The mole heat capacity Cp can be calculated from Eq. (13). The fitted heat capacity of single-crystal Mg2Si is 76.3 J/mol-K. The simulated results approach the Dulong-petit limit of 74.8 J/mol-K and keep consistent with the results calculated by Yu et al. based on first principles method [14].

The phonon transport of solids can be effectively calculated by two common theoretical approaches. One is the continuum transport theory, which is suitable for fast calculation of large system. Li et al. employed the linearized Boltzmann transport equation (BTE) for phonons to investigate the bulk and nanowire Mg2SixSn1 − x alloys [57]. However, it usually demands to obtain some parameters as the input by experimental or theoretical calculations. The other is the atomistic calculation such as MD simulation. MD method, which can provide fruitful insights into detailed physical mechanism at atomic level, has been widely applied in chemical physics, material science and bioengineering [58–60]. This method provides a very powerful way to study the thermodynamic properties of nanoscale materials where the experiments are quite difficult to implement. In our study, a reverse Non-Equilibrium molecular dynamics (NEMD) method proposed by Muller-Plathe [61] is adopted to compute the lattice thermal conductivity of single-crystal Mg2Si in the temperature range of 300–800 K.

The thermal conductivity
k
of a solid along a particular direction, taken here as the y axis, is defined by
(20)
k
y
= - Jy
1
∂ T / ∂ y
(21)
Jy =
1
A
Δ E
Δ t
where
∂ T / ∂ y
is the gradient of temperature along the y axis,
Jy
is the heat flux vector which is defined as the amount of energy (
Δ E
) transferred in a given time (
Δ t
) through the cross-sectional area (A) which is perpendicular to the flux direction. In the NEMD method, the heat flux is imposed on the system and the temperature gradient is the resulting response. As depicted in Fig. 6 , the simulation box is divided into N layers along y axis, where the layer 1 is the cold region and layer N/2 + 1 is the hot region. The kinetic energy is artificially transferred from the cool region to the hot region and then flows back by thermal conduction. In order to symmetric the temperature profile along the direction of the heat flux, periodic boundary conditions are applied in the calculation.

Along the three perpendicular directions, the box size of Lx = 31.69 Å, Ly = 1267.6 Å, Lz = 31.69 Å are performed. Firstly, two systems run for 50,000 steps and relax with NPT ensemble to reach a freestanding state at room temperature. Then the systems change to NVE ensemble to run for another 50,000 steps to reach equilibrium. After 100,000 steps of relaxation, two systems are divided into 60 layers along [0 1 0] directions, and exchange the kinetic energy every 100 steps until 1,000,000 steps are completed.

The cumulative kinetic energy transferred by these swaps and the resulting temperature profile are plotted in Fig. 7 (a) and (b) respectively. As shown in Fig. 7(a), the energy increases linearly with the simulation steps and the system is at the equilibrium state after 1,000,000 steps. In Fig. 7(b), the temperature gradients also show good linear relation and symmetry. Based on Eqs. (20) and (21), the thermal conductivity of single-crystal Mg2Si at the length Ly = 1267.6 Å can be calculated and the value is the 30.69 W/mK.

However, because of the effect of phonon scattering that occurs at the interfaces between the heating and cooling regions, the calculated thermal conductivity is dependent on the system size [61,62]. The size effect on thermal conductivity obtained from NEMD method can be calculated by the following formula,
(22)
1
k
eff
=
1
k
∞
+
b
L
where
k
eff
represents the thermal conductivity in a system with a length of L,
k
∞
represents bulk thermal conductivity, L is system length along the direction of heat flux. And b is length effect coefficient, which is related to density of atoms, phonon velocity, and Boltzman constant.

Therefore, the different systems with Ly = 443.716 Å, 507.04 Å, 570.42 Å, 633.8 Å, 1267.6 Å, Lx = 31.69 Å, Lz = 31.69 Å are performed to study the size effect on lattice thermal conductivity of single-crystal Mg2Si.

Fig. 8 gives the relationship between 1/k and 1/L along y-axis at the 300 K. By fitting Eq. (22), the lattice thermal conductivity
k
∞
at 300 K can be obtained extrapolating down to 1/L = 0. The obtained bulk thermal conductivity of single-crystal Mg2Si at 300 K is 106.72 W/mK. No experimental measurements on thermal conductivity of single-crystal Mg2Si are available to date. According to the experimental data of polycrystalline Mg2Si by Tani et al. [63], Yang et al. [64], and Akasaka et al. [65], the thermal conductivity of polycrystalline Mg2Si are almost 10 W/mK at room temperature. Comparing thermal conductivity values of polycrystalline, the calculated results of single-crystal Mg2Si by MD simulations are much higher, which can be attributed to the ideal simulation model, grain boundary scattering and point defects, and so on. The existence of strong grain boundary scattering and various defects can greatly reduce the lattice conductivity of materials [66–69]. Indu [66] investigated the low-temperature lattice thermal conductivity of polycrystalline Mg2Si, and experimental results also indicated that the boundaries and point defects significantly influenced its thermal conductivity. In order to identify the effect of defects on the lattice thermal conductivity, a simple point defect with 5% Mg atom vacancy has been considered, and the results including ideal and vacancy defect are all shown in Fig. 9 . As depicted, the presence of 5% Mg atom vacancy leads to large reduction in the lattice thermal conductivity. At 300 K, the lattice thermal conductivity with 5% Mg vacancy is 8.97 W/mK, which is close to that of the polycrystalline Mg2Si from the experiment. However, comparing the 106.72 W/mK of ideal single-crystal at 300 K, the lattice thermal conductivity of single-crystal with vacancy defect has dropped by almost 92%. It can be found that the Mg atom vacancy defect has a strong effect on the lattice thermal conductivity of single-crystal Mg2Si. In addition, the phonon mean free paths and phonon velocities in the ideal single-crystal and 5% Mg vacancy model are also calculated. The results show that phonon mean free path and phonon velocity for ideal single-crystal model are 79.8 nm and 4201 m/s, respectively. However, because of the 5% Mg vacancy in Mg2Si, the corresponding phonon mean free path and phonon velocity decreases to 10 nm and 2821 m/s, respectively. This demonstrates that the vacancy defect greatly declines the phonon mean free path and phonon velocity, which leads to the significant reduction of the lattice thermal conductivity of single-crystal Mg2Si. Zhang et al. [68] investigated different kinds of point effects including Mg vacancy on the thermal conductivity of bulk Mg2Si. The simulation results indicate that point defects at low concentrations can effectively reduce the thermal conductivity by 60–80%, which agrees well with our theoretical prediction. In the practical experiment, other various defects such as doping, atom filling, substitution and nanopores in thermoelectric materials would all suppress the lattice thermal conductivity of a material. Liu’s [27] experimental investigation successfully dropped the lattice thermal conductivity of polycrystalline Mg2Si into almost 1.5 W/mK at 300 K by atom doping and substitution. Comparing values of the pure polycrystalline Mg2Si, the thermal conductivity reduced by ∼85%.

In this study, the Multi-body interatomic potentials involving bond and angle interactions have been constructed for Mg2Si by first principles method. And then conventional MD simulation on elastic and thermodynamic properties is performed to verify the feasibility of potentials. The main conclusions are as follows.
(i)
The interatomic potentials which comprise of bond and angle atomic interactions have been successfully constructed based on the crystal structure characteristics. And parameters of the interatomic potentials are determined by the fitting into elastic properties obtained from first principles calculation and experimental results.
(ii)
The conventional MD simulation is preformed to validate the reliability of the interatomic potential by calculations of RDF, structural and the elastic properties of Mg2Si. The RDF results show that the Mg2Si maintains correct crystal structure after relaxation at room temperature. The calculated results of structural and elastic properties agree very well with the first principle and experimental data. Thus, the established interatomic potentials for Mg2Si are proven to be suitable for predictions of thermodynamic properties.
(iii)
Moreover, the thermodynamic properties including the linear expansion coefficient, heat capacity and thermal conductivity of single-crystal Mg2Si are also calculated for further validation. Thermal expansion coefficient, which is obtained from the temperature derivative of the lattice constant, is in good agreement with experimental results at 300 K. The calculated heat capacity approaches the Dulong-petit limit and agrees well with the heat capacity results from the first principle method. Finally, the lattice thermal conductivity of single-crystal Mg2Si is studied by the NEMD method. It is found that Mg atom vacancy has significant effect on the lattice thermal conductivity of single-crystal Mg2Si. The lattice thermal conductivity of single-crystal Mg2Si drops by about 92% from ideal single-crystal to 5% Mg atom vacancy. The lattice thermal conductivity with 5% Mg vacancy is 8.97 W/mK at 300 K, which is close to values of the pure polycrystalline from the experiment.

The MD simulation results indicate that interatomic potentials exhibit great reliability, and the potentials can be also used to study other defects on the elastic and thermodynamic properties of Mg2Si in the future work.

This work is financially supported by the National Program on Key Basic Research Project (973 Program, No. 2013CB632505), National High-tech R&D Program of China (863 Program, No. 2012AA051104), International Science & Technology Cooperation Program of China (No. 2011DFB60150), National Natural Science Foundation of China (Nos. 10672127 and 51272198), and the Fundamental Research Funds for the Central Universities (No. 2012-Ia-036).
